Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Coordinated Detection and Tracking of Hazardous Agents with Aerial and Aquatic Robots to Inform Emergency Responders

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
New tools and technology are needed to rapidly assess hazardous agents in the environment and inform emergency responders. Unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) have been used to monitor pollutant plumes in aquatic environments. However, USVs can only provide a close-up view of the plumes. Unmanned aerial systems (UASs) can survey large areas, but only from a distance. This project addresses the challenges in tracking flows of pollutants using a team of UASs and USVs. UASs are used as scouts to direct USVs to efficiently sample the water for testing. The results will provide emergency responders with technology that can provide rapid, actionable information on the dispersal of hazardous agents. This technology will be of immediate value in the development of early-warning systems for airborne hazards such as chemicals and radioactive particles. In an effort to encourage careers in robotics and emergency response, this project delivers a unique interdisciplinary robotics unit for 75 high school students.

Efficient coordination algorithms are required to fully exploit heterogeneity in sensing of teams of autonomous surface and aerial vehicles. When moving through the water, a plume of hazardous agents may bifurcate into different flow regimes, complicating the sampling and control scenario. This project: (1) develops approximation algorithms for multi-resolution, informative trajectory planning to track spatio-temporal plumes with UAS teams; (2) develops an autonomous USV to sample and characterize a surrogate hazardous agent in the water and air; (3) conducts field sampling campaigns with emergency responders (Virginia Tech Rescue Squad, a unique group of stakeholders consisting of >50 student members) to find and localize sources of a surrogate hazardous agent; and (4) develops a unique interdisciplinary robotics unit for 75 high school students representing a range of ages, ethnicities, and socioeconomic classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This overall goal of this project was to address the algorithmic and systems challenges in tracking plumes of hazardous agents with aerial and aquatic robots working alongside humans. Teams of unmanned aerial systems (UASs), unmanned surface vehicles (USVs), and underwater vehicles (ROVs) were used to detect, map, and track fluorescent dyes (surrogate agents), harmful algal blooms (HABs) and associated toxins, and simulated drowning victims. These robot teams were ultimately designed and operated to work together alongside humans to better inform emergency responders of hazardous agent dispersal and locate potential drowning victims.

Our work has contributed new unmanned systems technology to track the movement of hazardous agents in the air and water, and to assist with search and rescue missions for potential drowning victims. Such technology could find immediate use by state and federal agencies and groups of citizen scientists to monitor bodies of water for hazardous agents and drowning victims. Our work has demonstrated the value of coordinated unmanned systems to detect, track, and assist in mitigating HABs in freshwater systems. Fast response is essential in reacting to a HAB, in order to quickly predict and contain its spread.

Our project has led to the development of new coordination and planning algorithms for detecting, mapping, and tracking spatiotemporal plumes of hazardous agents using a team of heterogenous (air/surface) robots. The first set of algorithms focused on rapidly detecting hazards in an unknown environment. These algorithms focused on mapping the extent of the static hazards as well as translating plumes of hazards. The second set of algorithms focused on tracking keypoints of the plumes using a team of agents. These algorithms were designed to operate with a limited communication bandwidth. Finally, we devised algorithms for coordination between aerial and surface vehicles to specifically sample at hotspots (i.e., points of maximum concentration) without any a priori knowledge of the extent of the hazardous agents. The aerial vehicles acted as scouts to find hotspots which can then be sampled at by the surface vehicles. We successfully evaluated these algorithms through theoretical performance guarantees, extensive simulations, and proof-of-concept experiments conducted with an aerial robot.

Teams of aerial and aquatic robots were used to track fluorescent dyes (surrogate hazardous agents) in freshwater lakes with aerial and aquatic robots. Dye concentration profiles measured with an unmanned boat were similar to the intensity of the plume as seen by raw and processed images from an aerial robot. An underwater robot equipped with two different dye fluorometers and an underwater GPS system revealed 3D concentration profiles of a dye plume along discrete tracks. A bioaerosol-sampling system was designed and deployed onboard an unmanned boat to collect microbes and monitor particle sizes in the atmosphere above a salt pond and a freshwater lake. A small UAS was used in a coordinated effort with the unmanned boat to collect microbes 50m above the surface of the water. Two different HABs were monitored with aerial and aquatic robots. A drone water sampling system was used to collect water samples from the surface of two different HABs. This system consisted of 3D-printed sampling device tethered to a drone, and was used to collect surface water samples at different distances from the shore. Toxin concentrations were determined from these samples. An underwater robot was used to quantify the extent of the HAB underwater.

Joint field campaigns were conducted with members of the Blacksburg Rescue Squad and the Virginia Tech Rescue Squad to track fluorescent dyes and locate a drowning victim underwater. These field campaigns included measurements of drift, obtained from aerial robots and a series of drifting assets with different leeway characteristics. The project provided outreach and mentoring opportunities for middle-school students as part of the Virginia Tech CEED?s Game Changineering workshop. Six undergraduate students from three different HBCUs participated in a mini field campaign during the second year of the project. Three Virginia Tech undergraduate students organized a Girls Engineering Change workshop as part of this project, and 15 young girls attended the workshop.

The project led to the training and professional development of several students and a research associate. Three PhD dissertations were supported by this award (Drs. Powers, Sung, and Zhou). Powers started his own company and is a post-doc at PNL working on atmospheric transport of agents. Sung is a post-doctoral researcher at MIT, and Zhou is a post-doctoral researcher at the University of Pennsylvania--both are working on multi-robot coordination algorithms. An REU student, Bryan Bloomfield from HBCU Moorehouse, tracked HABs with aerial and aquatic robots. One notable team of undergraduate students (Team EARL) mentored by Schmale developed an underwater robot (EARL) tethered to an unmanned boat to assist in search and rescue missions. This award-winning team of students located a simulated drowning victim (a sunken rescue manikin) in minutes using EARL tethered to an unmanned boat.
